recipes.title: Allspice
recipes.content: A pea-sized fruit that grows in Mexico, Jamaica, Central and South America. Its delicate flavor resembles a blend of cloves, cinnamon and nutmeg. USES: (Whole) Pickles, meats, boiled fish, gravies. (Ground) Puddings, relishes, fruit preserves, baking.

recipes.title: Basil
recipes.content: The dried leaves and stems of an herb grown in the United States and North Mediterranean area. Has an aromatic, leafy flavor. USES: For flavoring tomato dishes and tomato paste, turtle soup; also use in cooked peas, squash, snap beans; sprinkle chopped over lamb chops and poultry.

nutrition.source: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis

recipes.title: Bay Leaves
recipes.content: The dried leaves of an evergreen grown in the eastern Mediterranean countries. Has a sweet, herbaceous floral spice note. USES: For pickling, stews, for spicing sauces and soup. Also use with a variety of meats and fish.

recipes.title: Caraway
recipes.content: The seed of a plant grown in the Netherlands. Flavor that combines the tastes of Anise and Dill. USES: For the cordial Kummel, baking breads; often added to sauerkraut, noodles, cheese spreads. Also adds zest to French fried potatoes, liver; canned asparagus.

recipes.title: Curry Powder
recipes.content: A ground blend of ginger, turmeric, fenugreek seed, as many as 16 to 20 spices. USES: For all Indian curry recipes such as lamb, chicken, and rice, eggs, vegetables, and curry puffs.

recipes.title: Dill
recipes.content: The small, dark seed of the dill plant grown in India, having a clean, aromatic taste. USES: Dill is a predominant seasoning in pickling recipes; also adds pleasing flavor to sauerkraut, potato salad, cooked macaroni, and green apple pie.

recipes.title: Mace
recipes.content: The dried covering around the nutmeg seed. Its flavor is similar to nutmeg, but with a fragrant, delicate difference. USES: (Whole) For pickling, fish, fish sauce, stewed fruit. (Ground) Delicious in baked goods, pastries and doughnuts, adds unusual flavor to chocolate desserts.

recipes.title: Marjoram
recipes.content: An herb of the mint family, grown in France and Chile. Has a minty-sweet flavor. USES: In beverages, jellies and to flavor soups, stews, fish, sauces. Also excellent to sprinkle on lamb while roasting.

recipes.title: MSG (Monosodium Glutamate)
recipes.content: A vegetable protein derivative for raising the effectiveness of natural food flavors. USES: Small amounts, adjusted to individual taste, can be added to steaks, roasts, chops, seafoods, stews, soups, chowder, chop suey and cooked vegetables.

recipes.title: Oregano
recipes.content: A plant of the mint family and a species of marjoram of which the dried leaves are used to make an herb seasoning. USES: An excellent flavoring for any tomato dish, especially pizza, chili con carne, and Italian specialties.

recipes.title: Paprika
recipes.content: A mild, sweet red pepper growing in Spain, Central Europe and the United States. Slightly aromatic and prized for brilliant red color. USES: A colorful garnish for pale foods, and for seasoning Chicken Paprika, Hungarian Goulash, salad dressings.

recipes.title: Poppy Seeds
recipes.content: The seed of a flower grown in Holland. Has a rich fragrance and crunchy, nut-like flavor. USES: Excellent as a topping for breads, rolls and cookies. Also delicious in buttered noodles.

recipes.title: Rosemary
recipes.content: An herb (like a curved pine needle) grown in France, Spain, and Portugal, and having a sweet, fresh taste. USES: In lamb dishes, in soups, stews and to sprinkle on beef before roasting.

recipes.title: Sage
recipes.content: The leaf of a shrub grown in Greece, Yugoslavia and Albania. Flavor is camphora-ceous and minty. USES: For meat and poultry stuffing, sausages, meat loaf, hamburgers, stews and salads.

nutrition.source: Better Homes and Gardens cookbook nutrition analysis

recipes.title: Thyme
recipes.content: The leaves and stems of a shrub grown in France and Spain. Has a strong, distinctive flavor. USES: For poultry seasoning, in croquettes, fricassees and fish dishes. Also tasty on fresh sliced tomatoes.

recipes.title: Turmeric
recipes.content: A root of the ginger family, grown in India, Haiti, Jamaica and Peru, having a mild, ginger-pepper flavor. USES: As a flavoring and coloring in prepared mustard and in combination with mustard as a flavoring for meats, dressings, salads.

recipes.title: Measurement Equivalents Chart
recipes.content: Common measurement equivalents: 3 tsp = 1 Tbsp | 2 Tbsp = 1/8 cup | 4 Tbsp = 1/4 cup | 8 Tbsp = 1/2 cup | 16 Tbsp = 1 cup | 5 Tbsp + 1 tsp = 1/3 cup | 12 Tbsp = 3/4 cup | 4 oz = 1/2 cup | 8 oz = 1 cup | 16 oz = 1 lb | 1 oz = 2 Tbsp fat or liquid | 2 cups = 1 pt | 2 pt = 1 qt | 4 qt = 1 gal | 1 jigger = 1-1/2 fl oz (3 Tbsp) | 8 to 10 egg whites = 1 cup | 12 to 14 egg yolks = 1 cup | 1 cup unwhipped cream = 2 cups whipped | 1 lb shredded American cheese = 4 cups.

recipes.title: Ingredient Substitutions
recipes.content: Substitutions for missing ingredients: 1 square chocolate (1 oz) = 3-4 Tbsp cocoa + 1/2 Tbsp fat | 1 Tbsp cornstarch (for thickening) = 2 Tbsp flour | 1 cup sifted all-purpose flour = 1 cup + 2 Tbsp sifted cake flour | 1 cup sifted cake flour = 1 cup - 2 Tbsp sifted all-purpose flour | 1 tsp baking powder = 1/4 tsp baking soda + 1/2 tsp cream of tartar | 1 cup sour milk = 1 cup sweet milk + 1 Tbsp vinegar or lemon juice (stirred) | 1 cup sweet milk = 1 cup sour milk or buttermilk + 1/2 tsp baking soda | 3/4 cup cracker crumbs = 1 cup bread crumbs | 1 cup cream, sour, heavy = 1/3 cup butter + 2/3 cup milk | 1 tsp dried herbs = 1 Tbsp fresh herbs | 1 cup whole milk = 1/2 cup evaporated milk + 1/2 cup water OR 1 cup reconstituted nonfat dry milk + 1 Tbsp butter | 2 oz compressed yeast = 3 (1/4 oz) packets dry yeast | 1 Tbsp instant minced onion = 1 small fresh onion | 1 Tbsp prepared mustard = 1 tsp dry mustard | 1/8 tsp garlic powder = 1 small pressed clove garlic | 1 lb whole dates = 1-1/2 cups pitted and cut | 3 medium bananas = 1 cup mashed | 3 cups dry corn flakes = 1 cup crushed | 10 miniature marshmallows = 1 large marshmallow.

recipes.title: General Oven Temperature Chart
recipes.content: Oven temperature guide: Very slow oven = 250° to 300°F | Slow oven = 300° to 325°F | Moderate oven = 325° to 375°F | Medium hot oven = 375° to 400°F | Hot oven = 400° to 450°F | Very hot oven = 450° to 500°F.

recipes.title: Contents of Cans - Standard Sizes
recipes.content: Standard can sizes and contents: 8 oz = 1 cup | Picnic = 1-1/4 cups | No. 300 = 1-3/4 cups | No. 1 tall = 2 cups | No. 303 = 2 cups | No. 2 = 2-1/2 cups | No. 2-1/2 = 3-1/2 cups | No. 3 = 4 cups | No. 10 = 12 to 13 cups.

recipes.title: Food Quantities for 25, 50, and 100 Servings
recipes.content: Guide for cooking for crowds - selected items for 25/50/100 servings: BREAD: Rolls 4 doz/8 doz/16 doz, Bread 50 slices or 3 1-lb loaves/100 slices or 6 loaves/200 slices or 12 loaves | MEAT: Weiners (beef) 6-1/2 lb/13 lb/25 lb, Hamburger 9 lb/18 lb/35 lb, Turkey or chicken 13 lb/25-35 lb/50-75 lb | SALADS: Potato Salad 4-1/4 qt/2-1/4 gal/4-1/2 gal | VEGETABLES: Mashed Potatoes 9 lb/18-20 lb/25-35 lb, Canned Vegetables 1 #10 can/2-1/2 #10 cans/4 #10 cans | DESSERTS: Cake 1 10x12" sheet/1 12x20" sheet/2 12x20" sheets | BEVERAGES: Coffee 1/2 lb + 1-1/2 gal water/1 lb + 3 gal water/2 lb + 6 gal water.

recipes.title: Easy Blender Cleaning
recipes.content: Fill blender part way with hot water; add a drop of detergent; cover and turn it on for a few seconds. Rinse and drain dry.

recipes.title: Can Opener Cleaning
recipes.content: Loosen grime from can openers by brushing with an old toothbrush. To clean blades, run a paper towel through the cutting process.

recipes.title: Fix a Scorched Saucepan
recipes.content: Don't panic if you accidentally scorch the inside of your favorite saucepan. Just fill the pan halfway with water and add 1/4 cup baking soda. Boil awhile until the burned portions loosen and float to the top.

recipes.title: Double-Boiler Water Warning
recipes.content: A jar lid or a couple of marbles in the bottom half of a double-boiler will rattle when the water gets low and warn you to add more before the pan scorches or burns.

recipes.title: Remove Lime from Teakettles
recipes.content: To remove lime deposits from teakettles, fill with equal parts vinegar and water. Bring to a boil and allow to stand overnight.

recipes.title: Washing Fine China and Crystal
recipes.content: Before washing fine china and crystal, place a towel in the bottom of the sink to act as a cushion.

recipes.title: Remove Coffee and Tea Stains
recipes.content: To remove coffee or tea stains and cigarette burns from fine china, rub with a damp cloth dipped in baking soda.

recipes.title: Remove Stuck Food from Casseroles
recipes.content: To quickly remove food that is stuck to a casserole dish, fill with boiling water and 2 tablespoons of baking soda or salt.

recipes.title: Clear a Clogged Drain
recipes.content: To clear a sink or basin drain, pour 1/2 cup of baking soda followed by a cup of vinegar down the drain. Let the mixture foam, then run hot water. When a drain is clogged with grease, pour a cup of salt and a cup of baking soda followed by a kettle of boiling water.

recipes.title: Polish Silver with Baking Soda
recipes.content: Silver will gleam after a rubbing with damp baking soda on a soft cloth.

recipes.title: Grater Cleaning Tips
recipes.content: For a fast and simple clean-up of your hand grater, rub salad oil on the grater before using. A toothbrush works great to clean lemon rind, cheese, onion, etc. out of the grater before washing it.

recipes.title: Handle Fruit Pie Juice Spills
recipes.content: While baking fruit pies, does the juice runneth over? Shake salt into the spills. They'll burn to a crisp and can be easily scraped up with a spatula.

recipes.title: Remove Grease Splatters
recipes.content: Grease splatters or other foods that have dried on the stove, burner rings, counter appliances, etc., may be removed by applying dry baking soda to the spots, then rubbing with a damp cloth. Rinse with clear water, dry and enjoy the like-new look.

recipes.title: Remove Corn Silk Easily
recipes.content: A dampened paper towel or terry cloth brushed downward on a cob of corn will remove every strand of corn silk.

recipes.title: Remove Corn Kernels from Cob
recipes.content: An easy way to remove the kernels of sweet corn from the cob is to use a shoe horn. It's built just right for shearing off those kernels in a jiffy.

recipes.title: Test Egg Freshness
recipes.content: To determine whether an egg is fresh, immerse it in a pan of cool, salted water. If it sinks, it is fresh; if it rises to the surface, throw it away. Fresh eggs' shells are rough and chalky; old eggs are smooth and shiny. To determine whether an egg is hard-boiled, spin it. If it spins, it is hard-boiled; if it wobbles and will not spin it is raw.

recipes.title: Egg White Tips
recipes.content: Egg whites won't run while boiling or poaching if you'll add a little vinegar to the water. Eggs will beat up fluffier if they are allowed to come to cool room temperature before beating. For baking, it's best to use medium to large eggs; extra large eggs may cause cakes to fall when cooled.

recipes.title: Peel Hard-Boiled Eggs Easily
recipes.content: Egg shells can be easily removed from hard-boiled eggs if they are quickly rinsed in cold water first.

recipes.title: Fluffier Omelets and Never-Weep Meringue
recipes.content: For fluffier omelets, add a pinch of cornstarch before beating. For a never fail, never weep meringue, add a teaspoon of cornstarch to the sugar before beating it into the egg whites. Once your meringue is baked, cut it cleanly using a knife coated with butter.

recipes.title: Cover Meringue Pie Without Sticking
recipes.content: A meringue pie may be covered with waxed paper or plastic wrap with no fear of sticking, if you'll first grease the paper with oleo.

recipes.title: Bacon Tips
recipes.content: No 'curly' bacon for breakfast when you dip it into cold water before frying. Keep bacon slices from sticking together; roll the package into a tube shape and secure with rubber bands. A quick way to separate frozen bacon: heat a spatula over a burner, slide it under each slice to separate it from the others.

recipes.title: Keep Cheese Fresh
recipes.content: Cheese won't harden if you'll butter the exposed edges before storing. A cloth dampened with vinegar and wrapped around cheese will also prevent drying out.

recipes.title: Meat Cooking Tips
recipes.content: Thaw fish in milk. The milk draws out the frozen taste and provides a fresh-caught flavor. When browning any piece of meat, the job will be done more quickly and effectively if the meat is very dry and the fat is very hot.

recipes.title: Get More Lemon Juice
recipes.content: You'll get more juice from a lemon if you'll first warm it slightly in the oven.

recipes.title: Perfect Popcorn Tips
recipes.content: Popcorn will stay fresh and you will eliminate 'old maids' if you store it in the freezer. Running ice cold water over the kernels before popping will also eliminate 'old maids'.

recipes.title: Better Fried Chicken
recipes.content: After flouring chicken, chill for one hour. The coating adheres better during frying.

recipes.title: Store Bread Crumbs
recipes.content: Empty salt cartons with spouts make dandy containers for bread crumbs. A funnel is used for getting the crumbs into the carton.

recipes.title: Fix Lumpy Sugar
recipes.content: A sack of lumpy sugar won't be if you place it in the refrigerator for 24 hours.

recipes.title: Soften Brown Sugar
recipes.content: A slice of soft bread placed in the package of hardened brown sugar will soften it again in a couple of hours.

recipes.title: Potato Cooking Tips
recipes.content: Potatoes will bake in a hurry if they are boiled in salted water for 10 minutes before popping into a very hot oven. A leftover baked potato can be rebaked if you dip it in water and bake in a 350° oven for about 20 minutes. A thin slice cut from each end of the potato will speed up baking time as well.

recipes.title: Cut Onions Without Tears
recipes.content: You'll shed less tears if you'll cut the root end off of the onion last. No more tears when peeling onions if you place them in the deep freeze for four or five minutes first.

recipes.title: Easy Fruit Peeling
recipes.content: Scalding tomatoes, peaches, or pears in boiling water before peeling makes it easier on you and the fruit — skins slip right off.

recipes.title: Ripen Fruit Faster
recipes.content: Ripen green fruits by placing in a perforated plastic bag. The holes allow air movement, yet retain the odorless gas which fruits produce to promote ripening. To hasten the ripening of garden tomatoes or avocados, put them in a brown paper bag, close the bag and leave at room temperature for a few days.

recipes.title: Pan Frying Tips
recipes.content: When pan frying always heat the pan before adding the butter or oil. A little salt sprinkled into the frying pan will prevent spattering. Meat loaf will not stick if you place a slice of bacon on the bottom of the pan.

recipes.title: Prevent Food from Sticking
recipes.content: Vinegar brought to a boil in a new frying pan will prevent foods from sticking. Muffins will slide right out of tin pans if the hot pan is first placed on a wet towel. No sticking to the pan when you're scalding milk if you'll first rinse the pan in cold water.

recipes.title: Reduce Broiling Smoke
recipes.content: Add a cup of water to the bottom portion of the broiling pan before sliding into the oven, to absorb smoke and grease.

recipes.title: Hide Cooking Odors
recipes.content: A few teaspoons of sugar and cinnamon slowly burned on top of the stove will hide unpleasant cooking odors and make your family think you've been baking all day!

recipes.title: Prevent Boiling Over
recipes.content: A lump of butter or a few teaspoons of cooking oil added to water when boiling rice, noodles, or spaghetti will prevent boiling over. Rubbing the inside of the cooking vessel with vegetable oil will also prevent noodles, spaghetti, and similar starches from boiling over.

recipes.title: Better Rice
recipes.content: A few drops of lemon juice added to simmering rice will keep the grains separate.

recipes.title: Butter and Shortening Tips
recipes.content: Grating a stick of butter softens it quickly. Soften butter for spreading by inverting a small heated pan over the butter dish for a while. A dip of the spoon or cup into hot water before measuring shortening or butter will cause the fat to slip out easily without sticking to the spoon.

recipes.title: Measure Sticky Ingredients
recipes.content: Before measuring honey or other syrup, oil the cup with cooking oil and rinse in hot water.

recipes.title: Empty Catsup Bottle Faster
recipes.content: Catsup will flow out of the bottle evenly if you will first insert a drinking straw, push it to the bottom of the bottle, and remove.

recipes.title: Unmold Gelatin Easily
recipes.content: If you wet the dish on which the gelatin is to be unmolded, it can be moved around until centered.

recipes.title: Fix Over-Salted Food
recipes.content: If you've over-salted soup or vegetables, add cut raw potatoes and discard once they have cooked and absorbed the salt. A teaspoon each of cider vinegar and sugar added to salty soup or vegetables will also remedy the situation. If you've over-sweetened a dish, add salt. A teaspoon of cider vinegar will take care of too-sweet vegetable or main dishes.

recipes.title: Perfect Gravy Tips
recipes.content: Pale gravy may be browned by adding a bit of instant coffee straight from the jar — no bitter taste, either. If you will brown the flour well before adding to the liquid when making gravy, you will avoid pale or lumpy gravy. A different way of browning flour is to put it in a custard cup placed beside meat in the oven. Thin gravy can be thickened by adding a mixture of flour or cornstarch and water, added gradually, stirring constantly, while bringing to a boil. Lumpless gravy can be your triumph if you add a pinch of salt to the flour before mixing it with water. A small amount of baking soda added to gravy will eliminate excess grease.

recipes.title: Remove Fat from Soups
recipes.content: Drop a lettuce leaf into a pot of homemade soup to absorb excess grease from the top. If time allows, the best method of removing fat is refrigeration until the fat hardens. If you put a piece of waxed paper over the top of the soup, it can be peeled right off, along with the hardened fat. Ice cubes will also eliminate the fat from soup and stew. Just drop a few into the pot and stir; the fat will cling to the cubes; discard the cubes before they melt. Or, wrap ice cubes in paper towel or cheesecloth and skim over the top.

recipes.title: Revive Wilted Vegetables
recipes.content: If fresh vegetables are wilted or blemished, pick off the brown edges, sprinkle with cool water, wrap in paper towel and refrigerate for an hour or so. Perk up soggy lettuce by adding lemon juice to a bowl of cold water and soak for an hour in the refrigerator. Lettuce and celery keep longer if you store them in paper bags instead of cellophane. To remove the core from a head of lettuce, hit the core end once against the counter sharply. The core will loosen and pull out easily.

recipes.title: Whipping Cream Tips
recipes.content: Cream will whip faster and better if you'll first chill the cream, bowl, and beaters well. Soupy whipped cream can be saved by adding an egg white, then chilling thoroughly. Re-beat for a fluffy surprise! A few drops of lemon juice added to whipping cream helps it whip faster and better. Cream whipped ahead of time will not separate if you add 1/4 teaspoon unflavored gelatin per cup of cream. A dampened and folded dish towel placed under the bowl in which you are whipping cream will keep the bowl from dancing all over the counter top.

recipes.title: Brown Sugar Storage
recipes.content: Brown sugar won't harden if an apple slice is placed in the container. But if your brown sugar is already brick-hard, put your cheese-grater to work and grate the amount you need.

recipes.title: Microwave Softening Tips
recipes.content: Soften hardened brown sugar: place open box in microwave with 1 cup hot water, microwave at high for 1½ to 2 minutes for ½ pound or 2 to 3 minutes for 1 pound. Soften hard ice cream by microwaving at 30% power (one pint 15-30 seconds, one quart 30-45 seconds, half-gallon 45 seconds to one minute). Soften one stick of butter or margarine in 1 minute at 20% power. Soften one 8-ounce package of cream cheese at 30% power for 2 to 2½ minutes (3-ounce package 1½ to 2 minutes).

recipes.title: Microwave Thawing Tips
recipes.content: Thaw frozen orange juice right in the container. Remove the top metal lid. Place the opened container in the microwave and heat on high power 30 seconds for 6 ounces and 45 seconds for 12 ounces. Thaw whipped topping (4½ ounce carton) in 1 minute on the defrost setting. Whipped topping should be slightly firm in the center but will blend well when stirred. Do not overthaw!

recipes.title: Microwave Reheating and Refreshing
recipes.content: Soften jello that has set too hard by heating on a low power setting for a very short time. Dissolve gelatin in the microwave: measure liquid in a measuring cup, add jello and heat. There will be less stirring to dissolve the gelatin. Heat hot packs in a microwave oven (a wet finger tip towel will take about 25 seconds, depending on temperature of water used). To scald milk, cook 1 cup milk for 2-2½ minutes, stirring once each minute. To make dry bread crumbs, cut 6 slices bread into ½-inch cubes, microwave in 3-quart casserole 6-7 minutes or until dry, stirring after 3 minutes. Crush in blender. Refresh stale potato chips, crackers or other snacks by putting a plateful in the microwave oven for about 30-45 seconds. Let stand for 1 minute to crisp. Cereals can also be crisped.

recipes.title: Microwave Cooking Tips
recipes.content: Melt almond bark for candy or dipping pretzels (one pound takes about 2 minutes, stirring twice). If it hardens while dipping candy, microwave for a few seconds longer. Nuts will be easier to shell if you place 2 cups of nuts in a 1-quart casserole with 1 cup of water. Cook for 4 to 5 minutes and the nut meats will slip out whole after cracking the shell. When thawing hamburger meat, the outside will many times begin cooking before the meat is completely thawed. Defrost for 3 minutes, then remove the outside portions that have de-frosted. Continue defrosting the hamburger, taking off the defrosted outside portions at short intervals. To drain the fat from hamburger while it is cooking in the microwave oven (one pound cooks in 5 minutes on high), cook it in a plastic colander placed inside a casserole dish. Cubed meat and chopped vegetables will cook more evenly if cut uniformly.

recipes.title: Microwave Baking Tips
recipes.content: When baking large cakes, brownies, or moist bars, place a juice glass in the center of the baking dish to prevent a soggy middle and ensure uniform baking throughout. Since cakes and quick breads rise higher in a microwave oven, fill pans just half full of batter. Using a round dish instead of a square one eliminates overcooked corners in baking cakes. When preparing chicken in a dish, place meaty pieces around the edges and the bony pieces in the center of the dish. Shaping meatloaf into a ring eliminates undercooked center (a glass set in the center of a dish can serve as the mold). A crusty coating of chopped walnuts surrounding many microwave-cooked cakes and quick breads enhances the looks and eating quality. Sprinkle a layer of medium finely chopped walnuts evenly onto the bottom and sides of a ring pan or Bundt cake pan. Pour in batter and microwave as recipe directs.

recipes.title: Microwave Food Safety Tips
recipes.content: Treat fresh meat cuts for 15 to 20 seconds on high in the microwave oven. This cuts down on meat-spoiling types of bacteria. Do not salt foods on the surface as it causes dehydration (meats and vegetables) and toughens the food. Salt the meat after you remove it from the oven unless the recipe calls for using salt in the mixture.

recipes.title: More Microwave Tips
recipes.content: For stamp collectors: place a few drops of water on stamp to be removed from envelope. Heat in the microwave for 20 seconds and the stamp will come right off. Heat left-over custard and use it as frosting for a cake. Melt marshmallow creme in the microwave oven. Half of a 7-ounce jar will melt in 35-40 seconds on high. Stir to blend. Toast coconut in the microwave. Watch closely as it browns quickly once it begins to brown. Spread ½ cup coconut in a pie plate and cook for 3-4 minutes, stirring every 30 seconds after 2 minutes. Place a cake dish up on another dish or on a roasting rack if you have difficulty getting the bottom of the cake done. This also works for potatoes and other foods that don't quite get done on the bottom.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Meats
recipes.content: Beef calories per serving: Ground beef (lean, 10% fat, broiled) 4 oz = 248 | Sirloin steak (lean only, broiled) 4 oz = 245 | T-bone steak (lean only, broiled) 4 oz = 253 | Chuck roast (lean only, pot-roasted) 4 oz = 219 | Beef corned (medium-fat) 4 oz = 422. Pork: Boston butt (lean only, roasted) 4 oz = 279 | Pork chop (lean only, broiled) 4 oz = 308 | Pork loin (lean only, roasted) 4 oz = 288. Lamb: Chop (lean only, broiled) 2-3 oz = 122 | Leg (lean and fat, roasted, boneless) 4 oz = 317 | Shoulder (lean only, roasted) 4 oz = 233.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Poultry
recipes.content: Chicken calories: Broiled (meat only) 4 oz = 154 | Roasted (dark meat, no skin) 4 oz = 207 | Roasted (light meat, no skin) 4 oz = 170 | Canned with beans 1/2 cup = 179 | Canned without beans 1/2 cup = 255. Turkey: Dark meat (roasted) 4 oz = 230 | Light meat (roasted) 4 oz = 200 | Canned (boned) 1/2 cup = 207. Duck (roasted, meat only) 4 oz = 352.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Seafood
recipes.content: Fish calories: Cod (broiled with butter) 4 oz = 192 | Fish sticks (breaded) 5 sticks = 276 | Flounder (baked) 4 oz = 226 | Haddock (fried, breaded) 4 oz = 187 | Halibut (broiled with butter) 4 oz = 254 | Salmon (smoked) 4 oz = 254 | Tuna (canned in oil, drained) 1/2 cup = 158 | Tuna (canned in water) 4 oz = 144. Shellfish: Shrimp (fresh, breaded, fried) 4 oz = 255 | Shrimp (canned, drained) 10 medium = 37 | Crabmeat 3 oz = 85 | Lobster (cooked in shell, whole) 1 lb = 112 | Oysters (raw) 1 average = 65.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Dairy Products
recipes.content: Milk calories: Whole (3.5% fat) 1 cup = 159 | 2% fat 1 cup = 145 | Skim 1 cup = 88 | Buttermilk (cultured) 1 cup = 88 | Evaporated (unsweetened) 1 cup = 345 | Condensed (sweetened) 1 cup = 982. Cream: Half and half 1/2 cup = 162 | Sour 1 tbsp = 26 | Whipping (heavy, unwhipped) 1/2 cup = 358. Cheese: American (processed) 1 oz = 105 | Cheddar (domestic) 1 oz = 113 | Cottage (creamed, small curd) 1/2 cup = 112 | Cream cheese 1 oz = 103 | Mozzarella (part-skim) 1 oz = 79 | Swiss 1 oz = 104.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Eggs
recipes.content: Egg calories: Boiled or poached (1 large egg) = 79 | Fried with 1 tsp butter (1 large egg) = 99 | Scrambled with 1 tsp butter (1 large egg) = 111 | Eggnog (8% fat, Borden's) 1/2 cup = 171. Egg substitutes available for lower calorie cooking.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Breads & Grains
recipes.content: Bread calories per slice: White (firm-crumb type) = 53 | Whole wheat (firm-crumb type) = 56 | Rye (light) = 60 | Pumpernickel = 79 | French = 44 | Italian = 28. Rolls: Frankfurter or hamburger (1 roll) = 119 | Hard (1 roll) = 78. Cereals: All-bran 1 cup = 192 | Bran flakes (40%) 1 cup = 106 | Corn flakes 1 cup = 97 | Oatmeal (cooked) 1 cup = 132 | Rice (puffed) 1 cup = 60. Rice: White (long grain, cooked) 1/2 cup = 93 | Brown (long grain, cooked) 1/2 cup = 116.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Fruits
recipes.content: Fresh fruit calories: Apple (with skin, 2 1/2" diameter) = 61 | Banana (1 average) = 118 | Cantaloupe (1/2 melon, 5" diameter) = 58 | Grapes (fresh, 10) = 18 | Orange (1 fresh) = 71 | Peach (fresh, 1 average) = 38 | Pear (fresh, Bartlett) = 100 | Strawberries (fresh, whole) 1/2 cup = 27 | Watermelon (1 wedge, 4" x 8") = 322. Canned fruit: Peaches (in juice, 2 halves with 2 tbsp juice) = 45 | Pineapple (chunks, canned) 1/2 cup = 48 | Applesauce (unsweetened) 1/2 cup = 50.

recipes.title: Calorie Counter - Vegetables

recipes.title: Kitchen Tip: How to Knead Bread
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook
recipes.description: Learn the proper technique for kneading bread dough.

instructions.text: Kneading should be done on a lightly floured surface, a board or counter top; add a little more flour if the dough remains sticky. Knead 8 to 10 minutes until smooth and elastic; it should have tiny air bubbles under the surface.
Turn the dough on to a lightly floured board or counter top. With lightly floured hands, shape the dough into a ball and fold it toward you.
With the heels of hands, using a rolling motion, push it away. Give dough a quarter of a turn.
Knead 8 to 10 minutes; dough should no longer stick and will be ready for second rising or shaping, as recipe directs.

recipes.title: Kitchen Tip: Judging Ground Meat Doneness
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 244
recipes.description: Safety guidelines for cooking ground meat to proper doneness.

instructions.text: For safety's sake, we recommend cooking all meat loaves and meatloaf-type ground-meat patties to 170° or till no pink remains.
Ground-meat patties, with no other ingredients added, however, may be cooked till their centers are brownish pink (medium doneness).

recipes.title: Kitchen Tip: Candy Temperature Stages
recipes.source_note: Better Homes and Gardens New Cookbook, page 93
recipes.description: Guide to the different temperature stages when making candy.

instructions.text: Thread stage (230° to 233°): When a teaspoon is dipped into the hot mixture, then removed, the candy falls off the spoon in a fine, thin thread.
Soft-ball stage (234° to 240°): When the ball of candy is removed from the cold water, the candy instantly flattens and runs between your fingers.
Firm-ball stage (244° to 248°): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it is firm enough to hold its shape, but quickly flattens at room temperature.
Hard-ball stage (250° to 266°): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it doesn't flatten until pressed.
Soft-crack stage (270° to 290°): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, but pliable and elastic, threads.
Hard-crack stage (295° to 310°): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, brittle threads that snap easily.

notes: Always use a candy thermometer for best results
The water test is a backup method if you don't own a candy thermometer
